items.title: Conduct Search Engine Discovery and Reconnaissance for Information Leakage
items.description: Identify all the endpoints and domains used in the application. Search for network diagrams, source code, configurations, privileged credentials, and error messages.
items.tools: Google Dorking, Manual Review, Static analysis using MobSF, jadx, Hopper

items.title: Fingerprint Servers and Endpoints Used by the Target Application
items.description: Find the version and type of running server/endpoint to determine known vulnerabilities and the appropriate exploits (relevant for non-HTTP services as well).

items.title: Determine Third Party Libraries Included in the Application
items.description: Identify and fingerprint third-party libraries included embedded into the application package, checking for known vulnerabilities (CVEs) and ensuring they are recent versions. OS libraries are out of scope.

items.title: Identify All API Endpoints
items.description: Use static analysis to discover hidden endpoints. Perform API testing during dynamic analysis.

items.title: Test Local Storage for Sensitive Data
items.description: Verify that sensitive data stored locally is properly protected and not exposed.

items.title: Test Logs for Sensitive Data
items.description: Check that sensitive information is not logged or, if logged, is properly protected.

items.title: Determine Whether Sensitive Data Is Shared with Third Parties via SDKs or Frameworks
items.description: Assess whether sensitive data is unintentionally shared with third parties through embedded SDKs or frameworks.

items.title: Determine Whether Sensitive Data Is Shared with Third Parties via Notifications
items.description: Verify that sensitive data is not disclosed through notifications or is properly masked.

items.title: Determine Whether the Keyboard Cache Is Disabled for Text Input Fields
items.description: Ensure that keyboard cache is disabled for input fields containing sensitive data.

items.title: Test Backups for Sensitive Data
items.description: Check that backups do not contain sensitive data or that such data is securely protected in backups.

items.title: Test Memory for Sensitive Data
items.description: Verify that sensitive data is not exposed in memory or is protected if it is. Note: This is only relevant for apps dealing with secrets/cipher keys and may require advanced analysis.

items.title: Testing the Device-Access-Security Policy
items.description: Assess the security policies in place for device access and ensure they are properly enforced. Note: On iOS, the application's ability to govern the user's device configuration is limited.
items.tools: Device Security Policy Review, Manual Analysis

items.title: Test Symmetric Cryptography
items.description: Verify that symmetric cryptographic algorithms used in the app are secure and implemented correctly.

items.title: Review the Configuration of Cryptographic Standard Algorithms
items.description: Ensure that cryptographic standard algorithms are configured according to industry best practices.

items.title: Test Random Number Generation
items.description: Verify that any random number generation used for cryptographic purposes (e.g., key generation, nonce creation, tokens) relies on secure system-provided APIs or other approved cryptographic random functions. This check does not apply to non-cryptographic randomness (e.g. UI effects, game logic, shuffling, etc.).

items.title: Verify the Purposes of Keys
items.description: Verify that cryptographic keys are used for their intended purposes and are managed properly.

items.title: Test for Cryptographic Key Reuse
items.description: Ensure that high-security cryptographic keys (e.g., wallet keys) are not reused for low-security cipher tasks.

items.title: Test Remote Service Authentication
items.description: If the app provides users access to a remote service, some form of authentication, such as username/password authentication, is performed at the remote endpoint.

items.title: Test for Secure Session and Token Generation
items.description: Validate that both stateful session identifiers and stateless tokens are securely generated (e.g., randomly generated, signed with a secure algorithm) by the remote endpoint.

items.title: Ensure the Remote Endpoint Terminates Session on Log Out
items.description: The remote endpoint terminates the existing session when the user logs out. Beware potential external provider limitations (e.g., cloud services) where sessions may not immediately terminate and may be out of the clients control

items.title: Review Password Policy
items.description: A password policy exists and is enforced at the remote endpoint.

items.title: Test Login Functionality Against Brute-Force Attacks
items.description: The remote endpoint implements a mechanism to protect against the submission of credentials an excessive number of times. Check for rate-limiting, WAF implementation, or similar mechanisms

items.title: Test Session Timeout
items.description: Sessions are invalidated at the remote endpoint after a predefined period of inactivity and access tokens expire. This should be applied based on the usage context of the application (e.g. apps handling highly sensitive data such as banking apps should have a much shorter timeout compared to a social media app).

items.title: Review Biometric Authentication
items.description: Biometric authentication, if any, is not event-bound (i.e. using an API that simply returns true or false). Instead, it is based on unlocking the keychain/keystore.

items.title: Test Multifactor Authentication
items.description: Check whether a secure method of multi-factor authentication is available and enforced where relevant (apps dealing with highly sensitive data)

items.title: Review Sensitive Transactions
items.description: Sensitive transactions require step-up authentication.

items.title: Ensure Login Activity Functionality Exists
items.description: The app informs the user of all login activities with their account. Users are able view a list of devices used to access the account, and to block specific devices. This check is primarily focused on apps dealing with personal/sensitive data

items.title: Test for Encrypted Communicatons
items.description: Data is encrypted on the network using TLS. The secure channel is used consistently throughout the app.

items.title: Review TLS Settings
items.description: The TLS settings are in line with current best practices, or as close as possible if the mobile operating system does not support the recommended standards.

items.title: Review Certificates
items.description: The app verifies the X.509 certificate of the remote endpoint when the secure channel is established. Only certificates signed by a trusted CA are accepted.

items.title: Analyze Certificate Verification
items.description: The app either uses its own certificate store, or pins the endpoint certificate or public key, and subsequently does not establish connections with endpoints that offer a different certificate or key, even if signed by a trusted CA.

items.title: Test for Insecure Communication Channels
items.description: The app doesnt rely on a single insecure communication channel (email or SMS) for critical operations, such as enrollments and account recovery. This is highly dependent on the use-case of the application, primarily applicable to applications handling sensitive or personal information

items.title: Check App Connectivity and Security Libraries
items.description: The app only depends on up-to-date connectivity and security libraries. On iOS, this is almost always the case.

items.title: Validate Secure Update Channels
items.description: Ensure that in-app updates are downloaded over secure, authenticated channels and verified for integrity (e.g., signature checks). This is only relevant in very limited cases, such as when the an app is enterprise-distributed or apps that download executable content to run in interpreted environments (e.g. Javascript in a webview, Lua scripts). In these cases, the integrity and authenticity of these downloads should be reviewed.
items.tools: Burp Suite, Charles Proxy, Traffic Inspection

items.title: Review App Permissions
items.description: The app only requests the minimum set of permissions necessary.

items.title: Test Input Validation
items.description: All inputs from external sources and the user are validated and if necessary sanitized. This includes data received via the UI, IPC mechanisms such as intents, custom URLs, and network sources.

items.title: Review URL Scheme Implementations
items.description: The app does not export sensitive functionality via custom URL schemes, unless these mechanisms are properly protected.

items.title: Review IPC Implementations
items.description: The app does not export sensitive functionality through IPC facilities, unless these mechanisms are properly protected.

items.title: Test Javascript in WebViews
items.description: JavaScript is disabled in WebViews unless explicitly required.

items.title: Review WebView Protocol Handler Configuration
items.description: WebViews are configured to allow only the minimum set of protocol handlers required (ideally, only https is supported). Potentially dangerous handlers, such as file, tel and app-id, are disabled.

items.title: Validate Secure WebView JavaScript-to-Native Interactions
items.description: If native methods of the app are exposed to a WebView, verify that the WebView only renders JavaScript contained within the app package.

items.title: Review Object Deserialization
items.description: Object deserialization, if any, is implemented using safe serialization APIs.

items.title: Analyze Runtime Permission Enforcement
items.description: Compare declared permissions with those used at runtime to detect excessive privilege or permission abuse.

items.title: Test Jailbreak/Root Policy Enforcement
items.description: Ensure that the application not only detects rooted/jailbroken devices but also enforces security restrictions accordingly.

items.title: Review Error Handling
items.description: Error handling logic in security controls denies access by default

items.title: Review App Signing Certificate
items.description: The app is signed and provisioned with a valid certificate, of which the private key is properly protected.

items.title: Verify App is Built in Release Mode
items.description: The app has been built in release mode, with settings appropriate for a release build (e.g. non-debuggable).

items.title: Check for Left Over Debugging Symbols
items.description: Debugging symbols should have been removed from native binaries.

items.title: Check for Left Over Debug Code
items.description: Debugging code should have been removed, and the app does not log verbose errors or debugging messages.

items.title: Review Third-Party Components For Known Vulnerabilities
items.description: All third-party components used by the mobile app, such as libraries and frameworks, are identified, and checked for known vulnerabilities.

items.title: Review Exception Handling
items.description: The app catches and handles possible exceptions.

items.title: Review Memory Allocation
items.description: In unmanaged code, memory is allocated, freed and used securely.

items.title: Ensure All Offered Security Features are Activated
items.description: Free security features offered by the toolchain, such as byte-code minification, stack protection, PIE support and automatic reference counting, are activated.

steps.title: Upload logs
steps.description: This should include all associated traffic associated to the in-scope targets.

steps.title: Executive summary
steps.description: The executive summary should be written with a high-level view of both risk and business impact. It should be concise and clear, therefore it is important to use plain English. This ensures that non-technical readers can gain insight into security concerns outlined in your report.
